Kent Beck wrote:

snipped...

>While some people go so far as to say that tests *should*
>have one assertion each, I generally have one or two assertions per test,
>with a fair number of tests with 4, 5, or 6 assertions (I wonder if this is
>fat tail distribution? 
>

Agreed Kent, which is why I said 'aim' not 'should'.

;-)

>In all the years I have done testing frameworks this way, I've never missed
>seeing multiple failures from a single test case. Thinking back to my
>debugging experience, I think that 90%+ of the time when an assertion fails,
>a single change gets the whole test running. Can you tell me more about the
>situation in which you wanted to see multiple assertion failures for a
>singlde test?
>
>  
>

yes, if the assertions did follow though, we'd end up with lots of 
failures per-test which to me, could well hide or confuse the true 
issue. Fixing the first failing assert tends to fix the others too.  I 
see this when I have separated multiple asserts into multiple tests of 
one assert.

A (contrived) example: when testing a class that uses a RegEx. We could 
have a single test that fires lots of different values at it to ensure 
the RegEx used internally is working correctly. or we could have 
multiple tests that fire individual values.

I've used both approaches, tending to go with many single assertion 
tests when lots of values can be tested against it and a single test 
with many assertions when only a few variances are needed to test it.
